Problem:
Consider a complex system where the output signal \( z(t) \) is determined by applying a Laplace transform \( L \) to an input signal \( x(t) \). The transfer function in the Laplace domain is given by \( H(s) = \frac{s + a}{s + b} \), where \( a \) and \( b \) are constants.

If at time \( t_1 \), an intervention by applying a different modulation \( n(t) \) is made, resulting in \( L(n(t) z(t)) = N(s)Z(s) \) at \( t > t_1 \), will the final output \( Z_f(s) \) depend on \( N(s) \) and not be determined purely by \( H(s) \)?
Explanation: The intervention using \( n(t) \) introduces a new variable \( N(s) \) which modulates the already transformed output \( Z(s) \). Hence, the final output \( Z_f(s) \) is now \( H(s)M(s)N(s)X(s) \), clearly affected by \( N(s) \), and thus not determined solely by \( H(s) \).
